review.title: A Machine Learning Based Analytical Framework for Semantic Annotation Requirements
review.abstract: The Semantic Web is an extension of the current web in which information is given well-defined meaning. The perspective of Semantic Web is to promote the quality and intelligence of the current web by changing its contents into machine understandable form. Therefore, semantic level information is one of the cornerstones of the Semantic Web. The process of adding semantic metadata to web resources is called Semantic Annotation. There are many obstacles against the Semantic Annotation, such as multilinguality, scalability, and issues which are related to diversity and inconsistency in content of different web pages. Due to the wide range of domains and the dynamic environments that the Semantic Annotation systems must be performed on, the problem of automating annotation process is one of the significant challenges in this domain. To overcome this problem, different machine learning approaches such as supervised learning, unsupervised learning and more recent ones like, semi-supervised learning and active learning have been utilized. In this paper we present an inclusive layered classification of Semantic Annotation challenges and discuss the most important issues in this field. Also, we review and analyze machine learning applications for solving semantic annotation problems. For this goal, the article tries to closely study and categorize related researches for better understanding and to reach a framework that can map machine learning techniques into the Semantic Annotation challenges and requirements.

metadata.title: A MACHINE LEARNING BASED ANALYTICAL FRAMEWORK FOR SEMANTIC ANNOTATION REQUIREMENTS

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijwest.2011.2203 27The semantic web is an extension of the current web, where information is given a clearly defined meaning. Therefore, semantic information is one of the cornerstones of the semantic web. The process of adding semantic metadata to web resources is called semantic annotation. There are many obstacles to semantic annotation, such as multilingualism, scalability and problems related to the diversity and inconsistency of the content of different web pages. Due to the wide range of domains and the dynamic environments in which the semantic annotation systems need to be carried out, the problem of automating the annotation process is one of the most significant challenges in this area. To overcome this problem, various machine learning approaches, such as the semantic learning we are examining more closely, such as the semantic learning and the uncurrent problems we are facing in this area.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: This year, we will be able to put ourselves in a position to take the lead.

sections.heading: 2. SEMANTIC ANNOTATION
sections.text: In general, the annotation is defined as the process of adding notes and comments to documents, images, or other resources. In the Web domain, the annotation means that information such as notes, comments, links to source material, and so on must be added to existing Web accessories without altering the originals. This annotation means that it can also be distributed over the network, although it cannot be shared. The annotation process can be manual, automatic, and semi-automatic. Semantic annotation means that machines append understandable metadata to resources. We consider the semantic annotation as an idea of mapping to the entities in the semantic descriptions.

sections.heading: 3. RELATED WORKS
sections.text: These tools and systems, called semantic annotation platforms, can be classified based on the type of annotation method they use [12]. There are two primary categories, pattern-based and machine learning, as shown in Figure 2. Furthermore, platforms can use methods from both types of categories, called multi-strategy, to take advantage of the strengths and weaknesses of the methods in each category. Pattern-based approaches can perform pattern inventions or have patterns defined manually. Most of these methods follow the process in which an initial group of units is defined at the beginning and the corpus is scanned to find the patterns that contain the units. New units are discovered, along with new patterns. This process continues recursively until no more units are discovered or the user stops the process. Annotation can also be generated by manual rules to find entities in text models.

sections.heading: 4. CLASSIFICATION OF SEMANTIC ANNOTATION CHALLENGES
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 5. ANALYTICAL FRAMEWORK
sections.text: In this section, we present the analytical framework that demonstrates the efficiency of various machine learning applications in accomplishing some of the semantic annotation tasks, which is introduced in Table 1. It attempts to show the relationship between effective machine learning techniques for accomplishing some semantic annotation tasks and the development of the annotation systems.The classification of semantic annotation systems within this framework is based on machine learning approaches, so that there are five classes: • Supervised Learning • Unsupervised Learning • Semi-Supervised Learning • Active Learning • Hybrid of semi-supervised Learning and Active LearningIn an extensive and rapidly changing field of research such as semantic annotation, which is itself a cornerstone of the semantic web, it is not possible to review all approaches and tools that are continuously introduced every day.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we present a comprehensive, multi-layered classification of semantic annotation systems. This classification represents almost all of the challenges mentioned in various research. Due to the wide range of areas and dynamic environments in which semantic annotation systems must be performed, we discussed that automation of the annotation process is a critical prerequisite for semantic annotation systems. From this perspective, we presented an analytical framework in relation to these applications. Subsequently, we reviewed and analyzed machine learning applications to solve semantic annotation challenges such as ontology development, scalability, and in particular the automation problem. In this context, some of the annotation systems based on the important characteristics in this area will be reviewed. Results show that different learning approaches have a major impact on solving semantic annotation tasks. While most systems use monitored and unmonitored annotation systems in their methods, further research seems to be needed to reduce the costs of individual systems so that they can be considered partially overlaid.

referenceMentions.context: 28 cooperation [1].
In semantic Web, ontology acts as this shared repository of semantics [2].
This means that an ontology describes some application-relevant part of the world in a machine-understandable way [3].
In other words, ontology is considered as a tool that defines additional meanings that tagged to web pages and makes them available to be used by software agents and web applications [4].

This is a further step along the way from simple textual annotations, as the intention within the Semantic Web context is that this information will be accessible not only to humans but also to software agents [5].
Machine Learning is the study of computer algorithms that improve automatically through experiences [6].
Different machine learning approaches have been proposed for semantic annotation automation [7, 8].
Different machine learning approaches have been proposed for semantic annotation automation [7, 8].
In the Web domain, annotation means adding information such as notes, commentary, links to source material, and so on, to existing web-accessible documents without changing the originals [9].
We consider Semantic Annotation the idea of assigning to the entities in the text links to their semantic descriptions [10].
Manual annotation is more easily accomplished today, using authoring tools such as Semantic Word [11], which provide an integrated environment for simultaneously authoring and annotating text.

Manual annotation is also an expensive process, and often does not consider that multiple perspectives of a data source, requiring multiple ontologies, can be beneficial to support the needs of different users [12].
Semantic annotation in a manual manner can easily result in a knowledge enhancement bottleneck [13].
These tools and systems which are called semantic annotation platforms can be classified based on the type of annotation method used in them [12].
Annotation can also be generated by using manual rules to find entities in text [12].
An overview of semantic annotation and effective technologies [12]
The process of semantically annotating documents is a well-known challenge for the Semantic Web per se [14].
But technical challenges contain the problems that relate to implementation and performance of a semantic annotation system [5,12,15-19].
But technical challenges contain the problems that relate to implementation and performance of a semantic annotation system [5,12,15-19].

Supervised Learning Action [19] Uses classification for determining and separating different events Supporting Ontology Manual Domain dependent
RCSSAT [20] Relation classification by using a new lexicon to provide semantic behavior features of words, and using kernel method to model lexical features Manual General
AnnoTex [21] Annotating based on classifying documents by means of semantic similarities Supporting Ontology Manual Domain dependent
KZMCM [22] Using text mining for semiautomatically semantic annotation Supporting Ontology Semiautomatic Domain dependent
SOZEKAMM [23] Automation of the generation of an annotation schema for a given semantic domain using a supervised categorical clustering algorithm LIMBO Semiautomatic Domain dependent
CAFETIERE [24] Using text mining techniques to propose annotation suggestions Supporting Ontology Semiautomatic Domain dependent
Unsupervised BroMo [25] Using clustering for blogs and article semantic annotation Semiautomatic General
OEAKM [26] Built an ontology enabled annotation and knowledge management system that provides clustering and real-time discussion for collaborative learning Supporting Ontology Semiautomatic General
ASWSACC [28] A machine learning-based semantic web annotation tool that learns by mining association rules among words through the text.
EOAAC [29] Using association rule mining to extract cooccurrences of concepts Supporting and enhancing Ontology Semiautomatic Domain dependent

Semisupervised Learning Self-teaching SVMstruct [30] Proposing a novel selfteaching SVM-struct model to improve the performance of semantic annotation with fewer labeled examples Supporting Ontology Automatic General
LVNER [31] Presenting a simple semisupervised learning Automatic General
Active Learning ASCUM [32] Proposing a SVM-struct based active learning algorithm for automatic semantic annotation Supporting Ontology Semiautomatic General

Hybrid of Semisupervised and Active Learning TM [33] A hybrid approach that annotate confident samples automatically and leave other uncertain samples to be labeled by a human annotator Semiautomatic General
LSWW [34] Proposing a combination of active learning and selftraining method to reduce the labeling effort for Chinese Named Entity Recognition and Annotation Semiautomatic General
1L-SP SSAL [35] A token level combination of semi-supervised and active learning with a variance based confidence measure Semiautomatic General

metadata.abstractText: The Semantic Web is an extension of the current web in which information is given well-defined meaning. The perspective of Semantic Web is to promote the quality and intelligence of the current web by changing its contents into machine understandable form.
